title: 5.0 Architecture Thread - Fix Governance Interface Architecture

body:
There are other things that should probably be changed as well such as:

    function votingPeriod() public view virtual returns (uint256);
    function votingDelay() public view virtual returns (uint256);

and pretty much every other function should be scoped to the proposal or have some identifier.  Currently the Voting Period, and delay are all tied down to the governor,  Ideally this architecture should be flexible enough to handle different types of votes.

e.g For instance some operations should be scoped to only certain members within the organization, 

 Image someone wanted to create emergency operations and only allow trusted interal members to handle proposing or voting on paticular internal things.

Currently the Time Delays, and voting periods get votes etc, are tied into the governor, when really that is something that should be more dynamic.  Emergency votes may want shorter delays etc for critical operations.

> ```
> function execute(
>      uint256 proposalId,
>      address[] memory targets,
>      uint256[] memory values,
>      bytes[] memory calldatas,
>      bytes32 descriptionHash
>  ) public payable virtual returns (uint256);
> ```

How do you ensure that the parameters match with what was included in the original call to `propose`? If you do that by hashing, you don't need the `proposalId` there. If you do that through data in storage, this is what the `GovernorCompatibilityBravo` does but it offers an alternative interface `execute(uint256 proposalId)` because it's not necessary to pass the remaining parameters, 
they are implicit.

---



> Currently the Time Delays, and voting periods get votes etc, are tied into the governor, when really that is something that should be more dynamic. Emergency votes may want shorter delays etc for critical operations.

Conceptually this makes sense, but I don't agree with the proposed implementation.

The Governor will have permissions assigned to it, over treasury, over upgrades, etc. The parameters are tied to those permissions, e.g.: "the system can be upgraded with a voting period of 14 days and 40% quorum". I should not be able to choose the parameters when I create a proposal, they should be determined by what the proposal does, and what permissions it requires. So I think when it comes to having different kinds of proposals that require different parameters, that should be implemented by having different Governor instances, which have different permissions assigned to them.
